conclusion: Objects C and D are under the blue fabric; objects E and F are under the checkered fabric; objects A and B are not yet placed.
Objects A and B are moved through the air and placed at the locations of objects C, D, E, and F.
Due to gravity, objects A and B will come into contact with the fabrics covering objects C, D, E, and F.
Object A creates a depression in the blue fabric covering objects C and D.
Object B creates a depression in the checkered fabric covering objects E and F.
The fabrics will sag or dip downward where objects A and B are placed.
If the fabrics are light enough or the objects are heavy enough, the outlines of objects A and B might be visible through the fabric.
Gravity pulls objects A and B downward, causing them to press into the fabrics.
The flexibility and weight distribution of the fabric determine how much it sags.
The heavier the objects, the more pronounced the sag will be.
Depending on the fabric's transparency and the objects' shapes, the objects beneath might be partially visible through the fabric.
When objects A and B are placed on top of the fabrics covering objects C, D, E, and F, the fabrics will sag under the weight of objects A and B, creating visible depressions.
The outlines of objects A and B might be seen through the fabric, depending on the fabric's properties and the objects' weights.
